Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Control Strategy for 3D Printing of Micro-Scale Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing systems, often called 3D printers, are poised to displace conventional manufacturing operations in many meso-scale applications (parts from 1 to 100 millimeters in size). Similarly, 3D printing at the micro-scale (from 0.001 to 0.1 millimeters in size) has the potential to revolutionize the way that biological and chemical sensors and integrated circuits are prototyped and manufactured. 3D printers build up complex parts by depositing one thin layer of material at a time. Electrohydrodynamic jet, or e-jet, printing is a promising micro-scale version of this process. This project will add sensors to a standard e-jet printer, and apply an innovative control law to greatly improve the precision of the resulting parts. The control law is based on the observation that 3D printed features typically change very little from one layer to the next. By observing how a layer deviates from its desired shape, the baseline e-jet control can be modified to improve the accuracy of the next layer. In this project, an atomic force microscope will be integrated with an e-jet printer to measure the shape of each layer. To better correct the printing process, the electric field around each layer will also be measured. The technical research plan is integrated with educational outreach to initiate undergraduate "micro-maker" clubs and catalyze an open-source, bottom-up movement based on inexpensive ink-jet printing of custom microcircuits and sensors.

Micro-scale Additive Manufacturing, and in particular, electrohydrodynamic jet printing, has the potential to revolutionize 3D, functional, micro-scale device fabrication. Limiting this step change in manufacturing capabilities is the reliance of micro-scale Additive Manufacturing systems on a process monitoring, regulation, and quality control paradigm that is performed post-process and in an ad hoc manner. This research will break this open-loop paradigm by generating fundamental scientific knowledge in two areas: 1) the synthesis of a controls theoretic framework to compensate for spatial disturbances with a robust and computationally efficient learning-based algorithm and 2) the study of interactions between charged jets of materials and substrates in electrohydrodynamic jet printing using first principles physics models and validated by empirical studies leveraging a novel integration of electrohydrodynamic jet printing and atomic force microscopy. This research will contribute the fundamental knowledge required to transform 3D micro-scale Additive Manufacturing from a nascent, open-loop and ad hoc technology set to a fully automated, accurate, and robust closed-loop system.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
3D printing has been called the next manufacturing paradigm. Interestingly, 3D printing is often associated with experimental concepts like a 3D printed car or as a prototype method for design. However, recent advancements have shown new and exciting uses for 3D printing, such as the development of printed sensors and electronics for smart surfaces. Unfortunately, slow speeds and inconsistent fabrication quality have limited the wide-spread use of 3D printing in many industries. Most commercial 3D printers suffer from a lack of process knowledge and control that leads to long process tuning cycles and failed printing jobs. To resolve these issues, this project focused on developing a new understanding of how surface interactions impact 3D printed devices, in particular a high-resolution jet-based process for customized sensor fabrication. This knowledge was combined with new controls theoretic tools from our collaborators to improve the performance of 3D printing processes at the microscale.

Intellectual Merit:  This project has provided a new understanding of how surface topology impacts the interaction and behavior of 3D printed materials. Through fundamental studies in first principles and high-fidelity simulation modeling, the relationship between surface shape and charge, material properties, and the interactions between printed droplets and the surface have been identified. This information has led to new developments in controls oriented modeling that have been used to inform the control theory necessary to enable regulated droplet merging on the substrate surface. Experiments carried out on a novel 3D micro-jet printer with atomic force microscopy measurement system, developed as part of this research, have demonstrated the validity of these interactions. Importantly, a new modeling method that combines a linear combination of high-fidelity models provides a fast estimation technique for near-real time surface predictions. The knowledge created by this project has resulted in six journal papers and nine conference papers.

Broader Impacts: This research has generated the baseline knowledge for understanding the interactions between surface topology and droplet merger that drive the final shape of a 3D printed device. The process knowledge obtained through this research can be directly translated to a better understanding of how to control 3D jet-based printing, particularly at the microscale. Micro-jet printing has extensive applications in high-resolution electronic, optical and biomedical device fabrication. Additionally, the simulation and modeling tools derived through this research provide a new method for high-speed interpolation of high-fidelity models. This can be advantageous for any process that would benefit from high-fidelity models, yet require near-real-time updates. The undergraduate students who contributed to various aspects of this work were given unique opportunities to disseminate their findings through conference presentations and outreach activities at the Ann Arbor Hands on Museum. The PhD student funded by this award will graduate this spring and is pursuing a career in academia.

 


Last Modified: 01/21/2019
Modified by: Kira Barton
